title: Improving multimodal physical function in adults with heterogeneous chronic pain; Protocol for a multisite feasibility RCT
abstract: Background: Chronic pain is associated with substantial impairment in physical function, which has been identified as a top concern among persons with pain. GetActive-Fitbit, a mind-body activity program, is feasible, acceptable, and associated with improvement in physical function among primarily White, sedentary individuals with pain. In preparation for a multisite efficacy trial, we must examine feasibility across multiple sites with diverse patient populations. Here we describe the protocol of a multisite, feasibility RCT comparing GetActive-Fitbit with a time-and attention-matched educational comparison (Healthy Living for Pain). We aim to 1) test multisite fidelity of clinician training; 2) evaluate multisite feasibility benchmarks, including recruitment of chronic pain patients taking <5000 steps/day and racial and ethnic minorities; and 3) optimize fidelity and study protocol in preparation for a future multisite efficacy trial. Methods: Clinician training fidelity was assessed via roleplays and mock group sessions. Feasibility (i.e., recruitment, acceptability, credibility, adherence, satisfaction), multimodal physical function (e.g., self-report, 6-Minute Walk Test, step-count), and other psychosocial outcomes are assessed at baseline, posttest, and 6 months. Protocol optimization will be assessed using exit interviews and cross-site meetings. Results: The trial is ongoing. Clinician training is complete. 87 participants have been recruited. 54 completed baseline assessments and randomization, 44 are mid-intervention, and 9 have completed the intervention and posttest. Conclusions: This study addresses the critical need for feasible, acceptable mind-body-activity interventions for chronic pain that follow evidence-based guidelines and improve all aspects of physical function across diverse populations. Results will inform a future fully-powered multisite efficacy trial.

sections.title: 1.. Introduction
sections.text:
Chronic pain (i.e. pain that persists for >3 months  [1, 2] ) is highly prevalent, engenders a significant economic burden  [3] , and is challenging to treat  [4] . It is among the most common chronic conditions in the US, with 50.2 million adults (20.5%) reporting that they experience pain on most days or every day  [5] . Physical function, a marker of overall health and wellbeing  [6] , is a multidimensional construct defined by the ability to perform activities of daily living  [7] , and has consistently been identified as a top concern by patients with chronic pain  [8] . A substantial body of research documents the relationship between chronic pain and physical function  [6, 9] , and indicates that this relationship persists regardless of pain location or severity  [10, 11] .

Walking, one of the simplest, safest, and most accessible forms of physical activity, has been shown to improve physical function outcomes among patients with chronic pain  [12, 13] . Indeed, among persons with pain, who tend to be more sedentary on average (i.e. taking <5000 steps per day)  [12, 14, 15] , walking has been identified as a preferred method of activity  [14] , and is acceptable, beneficial, and unlikely to cause harm in this population  [14, 16] . Nevertheless, among some individuals with chronic pain, pain catastrophizing and fear of increased pain as a result of walking have been identified as important barriers and may be associated with decreased walking program uptake or adherence  [14] [15] [16] [17]  as well as decreases in physical function  [18] [19] [20] [21] . Mind-body skills addressing catastrophic thinking about pain and fear avoidance can bypass these barriers to activity and may be an effective way to increase walking and thereby increase physical function among individuals with chronic pain.

Although the Initiative on Methods, Measurement, and Pain Assessment in Clinical Trials (IMMPACT) recommendations specify that physical function should be a required outcome in pain clinical trials, few studies include it  [22] [23] [24] . Further, to our knowledge, no trials to date have included the recommended comprehensive assessment of physical function using self-report, performance-based, and objective outcomes. To address this critical gap, we used the fear avoidance model and iteratively designed, developed, and refined the GetActive-Fitbit program (Fig.  1 )  [25] .

GetActive-Fitbit is a feasible, acceptable, and credible mind-body program that targets increased walking and utilizes Fitbit step tracking to provide real-time feedback and reinforcement of step goals  [26] . GetActive-Fitbit is associated with sustained improvement in all aspects of physical function among sedentary adults with heterogenous chronic pain, as well as with improvement in its putative mechanisms  [26] . Although successful, our feasibility trial had several limitations. First, we recruited participants from an urban hospital that sees primarily non-Hispanic White patients, which limited racial and ethnic diversity in the sample. Given the high prevalence of chronic pain among racial and ethnic minorities  [27] , as well as underrepresentation in clinical trials  [28] , it is important to test the feasibility and acceptability of our intervention among a sample representative of US population demographics with respect to racial and ethnic diversity. Second, our feasibility study recruited from only one site. Given our goal of eventually implementing the intervention in routine care across pain clinics in the US, it is important to test our ability to implement our study procedures across geographically diverse clinics. Third, despite global improvements in self-reported physical function in our feasibility trial, we observed improvement in objective physical function (i.e., stepcount) only among individuals who took fewer than 5000 steps/day at baseline (e.g., sedentary  [26, 29] ). Before conducting a fully-powered efficacy trial it is important to accurately select sedentary participants who are best positioned to benefit from the intervention. Fourth, the initial study did not include an attention-matched control group to compare against the group receiving mind-body and activity skills. Establishing the feasibility of our comparison condition is an important part of preparing for a future efficacy trial.

The current study builds upon our prior work and aims to address its limitations. We will conduct a multisite feasibility randomized controlled trial of GetActive-Fitbit versus a time-and attention-matched educational control (Healthy Living for Pain; HLP) among a diverse sample of sedentary adults with chronic pain recruited from pain clinics in three medical centers distributed across the South, the Midwest, and the Northeast. The present study has three aims: (1) Testing multisite fidelity of training and implementation of GetActive-Fitbit vs HLP among adults with heterogeneous, non-malignant, musculoskeletal chronic pain; (2) Evaluating multisite feasibility benchmarks, including ability to select chronic pain individuals who are sedentary, retain participants through 6-month follow-up, and recruit >38% racial and ethnic minorities (i.e., non-White and/or Hispanic/Latino  [30] ) and (3) Optimizing and refining our fidelity and study implementation procedures in preparation for a future fully-powered multisite efficacy RCT. Here we describe the study protocol.

sections.title: 2.1.. Study design and setting
sections.text:
This is a multisite, single-blind feasibility RCT conducted across three medical centers to compare GetActive-Fitbit to a time-and attention-matched educational comparison (HLP). All study procedures have been approved by the local and central institutional review boards.

Fig.  1 . GetActive-Fitbit study progression.

sections.title: 2.2.. Aim 1 -training of study clinicians
sections.text: The first aim of our protocol involved the training of study clinicians at each of the three sites in GetActive-Fitbit and HLP with standardized protocols. Fidelity to the protocol was assessed through role plays and mock group sessions (described below).

sections.title: 2.2.1.. Participants and procedures
sections.text: Study clinicians were 5 doctoral-level providers with training in clinical psychology. Clinicians attended 4 h-long training sessions with the Multiple Principal Investigator (MPI) who was the clinician of the prior trial. Training included presentations of the theoretical and empirical background of the program, review of treatment goals, challenges encountered in the prior MGH feasibility trial and strategies to problem solve them, treatment manuals, modeling of process factors (e. g., keeping participants engaged, confidentiality), and skills roleplays. Fidelity to the study protocol was assessed via recorded mock group sessions at each of the study sites. Mock groups were attended by research assistants assigned to roleplay case studies, which were scripted and developed by a clinical psychologist based on prior clinical and research experience with chronic pain patients. Our benchmark for clinician training included a score of ≥80% on post-training knowledge testing, and ≥ 8 on standardized adherence and competency rating scales of GetActive-Fitbit and HLP mock group sessions (1 = poor to 10 = outstanding).

sections.title: 2.2.2.. Training fidelity analysis plan
sections.text: To assess training fidelity: a) Clinicians completed post-training surveys assessing knowledge about the programs; b) Clinicians conducted video recorded mock groups of GetActive-Fitbit and HLP sessions; and c) Clinicians' adherence and competence in conducting mock intervention sessions was evaluated on standardized rating scales to establish training fidelity prior to delivery to participants. Clinicians completed adherence checklists after each session to record fidelity to the protocol and engage in weekly hour-long clinical supervision with a psychologist. Adherence checklists will be double-checked and assessed for fidelity by a trained doctoral-level clinical psychology fellow who will be trained and supervised by the MPIs. Clinicians provided qualitative feedback on any recommended modifications to training procedures to improve the training process.

sections.title: 3.. Aim 2recruitment, enrollment, and assessment of feasibility
3.1.. Inclusion and exclusion criteria
sections.text:
Eligible adults are individuals ≥18 years of age with chronic musculoskeletal pain (3+ months of nonmalignant pain). Other inclusion criteria are (1) English fluency and literacy, (2) ability to walk for at least 6 min, (3) willingness to participate and comply with study protocol, (4) free of concurrent psychotropic or pain medication or stable on current medication for a minimum of 6 weeks and willing to maintain a stable dose, (5) owns a smartphone or computer with Bluetooth capabilities, (6) sedentary, as measured by meeting 2/3 markers:  [1]  sits for 8+ hours per day,  [2]  exercises fewer than 3 days per week (30+ minutes of intentional exercise), and  [3]  walks fewer than 7 days per week (30+ minutes of walking). Participants with a smartphone may also reference the average step count recorded on the pre-installed Apple Health or Google Fit applications to determine their level of sedentariness (i.e., walking fewer than 5000 steps/day  [29] ).

Exclusion criteria include (1) diagnosed medical illness expected to worsen in the next 6 months, (2) serious, untreated mental illness for which hospitalization may occur, (3) active suicidal ideation, (4) unstable or untreated psychotic disorders (e.g., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia), (5) current untreated substance use disorder,  (6)  unable to walk/in a wheelchair,  (7)  practice of yoga, meditation, or other mindbody techniques for 45+ minutes per week for the last three months, (8) regular use of a smartwatch (i.e., Fitbit, Apple Watch) and unwillingness to discontinue use for the duration of the study, and (9) 4+ errors on the Short Portable Mental Status Questionnaire (ages 65+).

sections.title: 3.2.. Recruitment
sections.text: The "parent" site (Massachusetts General Hospital; MGH) began recruitment in April 2023. Recruitment at the two "child" sites (Duke Medical Center and Rush University Medical Center) was initiated in June 2023. The child sites were strategically selected because they have robust chronic pain clinics with a racially and ethnically diverse population and are distributed across the US. Participants are recruited via referrals from established provider partnerships at pain clinics and medical record review. IRB-approved flyers are placed in approved areas (i.e., outpatient clinics, community health centers, in the community) and distributed to chronic pain Facebook groups and site-specific recruitment websites (e.g., Partners Rally; an online research participant recruitment platform). Recruitment and study timeline are described further in Fig.  2 .

sections.title: 3.3.. Enrollment and testing
sections.text:
This study aims to enroll a total of 90 participants (N = 30 per site). Programs are delivered in-person with 3-10 participants per group, with 2-3 cohorts per site. Baseline sessions are scheduled one week prior to Session 1 to optimize participant availability, ensure consistency between group times, and leave sufficient time to collect baseline Acti-Graph wear data (>5 days of wear data prior to Session 1). The in-person baseline assessment includes four sections: informed consent, self-report surveys, the 6-Minute Walk Test (6MWT), and distribution of Acti-Graphs to wear for one week.

In-person assessments are repeated one week post-intervention and at 6-month follow-up. Participants receive ActiGraph devices at Session 10 for post-intervention testing and via mail one week before 6-month follow-up. Participants are invited to participate in an optional group exit interview to collect qualitative data on study procedures. Exit interviews are conducted in-person during post-intervention testing and follow a semi-structured IRB-approved script. Participants receive up to $945 for completing all assessments, procedures, and sessions.

sections.title: 3.4.. Measures
sections.text: Participants complete study measures electronically on the secure Research Electronic Data Capture (REDCap) platform during the baseline visit. RAs remain in the room to facilitate survey completion and answer participant questions. Participants complete measures assessing physical function, emotional function, putative mechanisms, and pain intensity and interference. They also completed a measure of perceived improvement, demographics, and participant characteristics (see Table  1 ).

sections.title: 3.4.1.. ActiGraph step count assessment
sections.text: To assess accelerometer step count-based physical function, participants receive an ActiGraph wGT3X-BT to wear for one week prior to the start of group sessions. Participants wear the device on their nondominant hand, and settings are customized based on participant height. Participants are instructed to download the Centrepoint app to sync their watch to their Bluetooth-compatible device, and to wear the device at all times, except when bathing or swimming. The RA and participant discuss individualized plans to ensure the daily wearing and syncing of the watch (e.g., using reminder sticky notes, setting alarms). The Centrepoint platform is used to track participant progress; reminder calls are conducted with non-adherent participants. Participants are considered compliant and "cleared" to return the device at the first group session if they tracked ≥4 days of valid wear data (>10 waking hours/day). Participants with <4 days continue to wear the device until reaching the 4-day threshold. Importantly, ActiGraphs do not display step count information for participant use, necessitating the use of the Fitbit for self-monitoring steps.

sections.title: 3.5.. Randomization to treatment arm
sections.text: Randomization occurs at the end of baseline assessments and is stratified by site (MGH, Duke, or Rush) to ensure an even distribution of participants among the intervention and comparison conditions at each site. Participants receive study materials during the first in-person session to ensure data were not influenced by treatment arm allocation; participants randomized to GetActive-Fitbit also receive a Fitbit.

sections.title: 3.6.. Treatment arms
sections.text: Group sessions (60 min) are delivered in-person for 10 weeks. Participants are considered enrolled (i.e., added to the enrollment goal) after attending the first study session. Table  2  outlines the GetActive-Fitbit and HLP session content.

sections.title: 3.6.1.. GetActive-Fitbit
sections.text:
GetActive-Fitbit encourages the gradual increase of walking using quota-based pacing (i.e., gradual increases in activity based on a set measure and noncontingent on pain)  [39, 40] . Participants receive individualized step goals based on Fitbit step count data and set weekly goals to slowly increase activity. Participants receive home practice assignments to reinforce session content, such as reviewing the manual and listening to skills-based audio recordings (e.g., deep breathing).

Participants also receive daily text message reminders with a survey that logs home practice.

3.6.1.1. Fitbit step count. Participants randomized to GetActive-Fitbit receive a Fitbit Inspire 3 and charger free of cost. An RA distributes the Fitbit at the first in-person group session and instructs each participant to sync the device to a Bluetooth-compatible smartphone using the free Fitbit application. Participants are expected to wear the Fitbit from the first session to post-assessments, excluding sleeping, bathing, and swimming. The RA uses Fitabase, a secure web-based platform, to remotely track participant wear adherence. The RA sends weekly emails to remind participants to charge and sync their device. The RA also uses Fitabase to calculate individualized weekly step count goals, which are emailed to participants prior to the group session. Consistent with prior work  [26, 39] , step goals are increased by 10% if participants reach their weekly goal, maintained if they do not reach their goal, and set to 10% more than their actual step count for the week if they miss their step goal for 2 weeks in a row. The RA manually adjusts step count goals in each participant's Fitbit application by remotely logging into their Fitbit account on an encrypted computer.

sections.title: 3.6.2.. Healthy living for pain
sections.text: Participants receive standard lifestyle advice for patients with chronic pain. Table  2  outlines session content. Participants receive similar clinician support to the GetActive-Fitbit condition, engage in journaling as homework following each session, and engage in discussion with group members at each session. Participants receive daily text message reminders to journal about session content.

sections.title: 6. weeks before intervention
sections.text: Week before intervention

sections.title: Start of intervention
sections.text: RA reviews consent with eligible participants and collects availability.

sections.title: Recruitment and Screening
sections.text: RA receives referrals/inquiries and screens via telephone or REDCap survey.

sections.title: Intervention (in person)
sections.text:
Study clinicians conduct 10-weeks of in-person group sessions. RA activates daily surveys to log adherence.

GetActive-Fitbit only: Participants receive Fitbit and sync device to smartphone.

sections.title: Post-Test Assessment (in person)
sections.text:
RA randomizes participants to GetActive-Fitbit or Healthy Living for Pain.

Participants receive ActiGraph to wear for one week. 10 weeks after intervention

sections.title: Follow-Up Assessment (in person)
sections.text: Participants repeat study assessments (self-report measures and 6MWT). RA distributes ActiGraphs to wear for one week.

sections.title: 3.7.. Feasibility markers
sections.text: Table  3  outlines feasibility benchmarks. We will assess fidelity benchmarks for training, recruitment, intervention, retention, and assessments. Fidelity to the intervention will be assessed using measures capturing both specific (e.g., reviewed all session elements, introduced new skills) and non-specific (e.g., time management, reinforcing active participation) elements of the session.

sections.title: 3.8.1.. Power analysis
sections.text: Although the present study is not intended to be statistically powered to detect treatment effects, our target sample of N = 90 (30 per site) is consistent with recommendations from prior trials  [41] . Based on our prior work, the target sample should provide good power to achieve our • Demographic measures included age, gender, sex, race, ethnicity, education, employment, income, marital status, mental health history, medications, medical conditions, and pain characteristics. Pre, Post, 6 months. • 6-Minute Walk Test via the Timed Walk app: Measures distance walked in meters at a fast pace for 6 min using smartphone GPS [31,32]. Post • Credibility/Expectancy Questionnaire [38]: Measures credibility and expectation about potential benefit from participation. Pre

sections.title: Review of Healthy Living for Pain
sections.text: Overview of program multisite fidelity and feasibility benchmarks. Specifically, if 90 participants are enrolled, the study will have an 80% probability of meeting all feasibility benchmarks if the expected proportion of participants enrolling, completing ≥7 of 10 sessions, rating the program as credible and satisfactory, and completing post-treatment follow-up is at least 89%, and if the expected proportion of protocol checklists deemed accurate is at least 94%. The planned sample size will also provide adequate precision for estimating fidelity and feasibility benchmarks. Collection of follow-up outcomes at 6 months will allow us to have an estimate of the rate of missing data, assess the acceptability of selfreport, and obtain estimates of variability to cautiously inform power calculations for the future multisite efficacy trial.

sections.title: 3.8.2.. Data analyses
sections.text: Following the assessment of feasibility benchmarks (see Table  3 ), we will use Fisher's exact tests or extensions to make comparisons between the number of people meeting each benchmark across study sites and between intervention arms, while also plotting performance metrics across sites to visualize differences. Estimates of variance components required for design of a future efficacy trial, including intraclass correlation coefficients will be obtained from preliminary analysis of selfreport, performance-based, and objective/ambulatory measurements in mixed model repeated measures analyses.

sections.title: 3.9.. Aim 3 -refinement of fidelity and study implementation protocol
sections.text: We expect that our data from exit interviews, site-specific and crosssite meetings, and "lessons learned" will allow us to refine training, study implementation, and standard operating procedures to be fully prepared for a fully-powered, multisite efficacy trial. Conducting exit interviews with chronic pain patients with diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds across the three sites will allow us to gather meaningful information on perception of intervention components, study protocol, home practice adherence, and interventionists. Focus groups with staff will allow us to gather information on feasibility of recruitment, retention, intervention, and assessments. We will use our expertise in qualitative methods to design the interview script and will analyze themes using a Rapid Data Analysis approach. We will conduct monthly local and quarterly multisite meetings to discuss overall results, anticipate potential systemic barriers and develop solutions, and discuss modifications for future iterations of the program. Feedback on how to optimize and refine the protocol will be collected at each step of the trial. The most effective recruitment and retention strategies across sites (including strategies that are matched to specific systemic barriers), will be identified and tailored to individual sites to maximize efficiency of recruitment in the subsequent trial.

sections.title: 3.10.. Exit interviews and focus groups
sections.text: At post-intervention, we will conduct one exit interview with each GetActive-Fitbit and HLP group to further understand barriers and facilitators to study participation, protocol implementation, and overall group experience. Focus groups will be conducted in the same groups as interventions were delivered. At the end of the study, we will also conduct focus groups with study staff at each site (e.g., research assistants, study clinicians, and referral sources) to qualitatively evaluate the study protocol and methodology. We will specifically collect information about barriers and facilitators to recruitment, retention, and study operations. We will also discuss systemic barriers and facilitators relevant to adding other sites in the future efficacy trial.

sections.title: 3.11.. Data analytic plan
sections.text: To optimize our fidelity and study implementation protocol procedures in preparation for a future fully-powered multisite randomized controlled efficacy trial, all exit interview data will be analyzed using a Rapid Data Analysis (RDA) approach in NVivo 12  [42, 43] . RDA is a valid and reliable qualitative data analysis method that is recommended in studies where there is a need for real-time data to inform intervention adaptation and implementation  [43, 44] . In an RDA framework, the process of transcription and in-depth coding is bypassed in favor of organizing the data immediately following qualitative interviews. Organizing templates will be created from the interview scripts immediately following each interview; these templates will be comprised of prespecified domains identified prior to exit interviews related to program implementation preferences, population needs, and barriers and facilitators to program implementation. Following guidelines for RDA, completed templates will be reviewed by a member of the research team and entered into a response matrix  [44] , which will be organized in a hybrid inductive-deductive manner. This matrix will incorporate domains identified for the RDA template as well as information from the exit interviews that may be useful in informing intervention adaptations.

sections.title: 4.. Results
sections.text: The trial is ongoing. Clinician training was completed in April 2023. Clinicians demonstrated excellent performance on the knowledge checks, scoring above the 80% threshold across the four surveys. We are in the process of calculating clinician fidelity during the mock group training. As of September 2023, MGH has recruited 48 participants and randomized 31 participants (16 GetActive-Fitbit and 15 HLP; M age = 50.1, 67.7% Female, 19.4% Non-White) across three group cohorts. Rush has recruited 18 participants and randomized 7 (3 GetActive-Fitbit and 4 HLP; M age = 61.2, 75% Female, 75% Non-White) across one group cohort. Duke has recruited 21 participants and randomized 16 (8 GetActive-Fitbit and 8 HLP; M age = 64.9, 57.1% Female, 85.7% Non-White) across one group cohort. Recruitment at Duke and Rush has been delayed due to multisite IRB linking procedures. Recruitment at these sites commenced in July 2023. See Table  4  for demographic characteristics of participants at each site by treatment arm.

sections.title: 4.1.. Initial protocol refinement
sections.text: Informed by "lessons learned" from our prior single-site feasibility trial  [26]  and the ongoing trial, we have refined our procedures to improve the protocol in several ways. First, we streamlined written materials in the manuals based on clinician feedback during training and participant feedback during sessions. During clinician supervision, tips for effective intervention delivery are shared between sites which increases clinician confidence and prepares clinicians for difficult situations they may encounter while delivering specific session content. Second, following participant feedback, we began offering to collect journaling assignments from the HLP groups. Third, we amended the Table  3  Feasibility benchmarks.

sections.title: Recruitment
sections.text:
• ≥80% eligible sedentary chronic pain patients will enroll after screening. • Recruit N = 90 patients within 12 months across the 3 sites with 34 (38%) of racial and ethnic minorities (i.e., non-White and/or Hispanic/Latino  [30] , reflecting the composition of the current U.S. Population  [46] ) Treatment Arms

• ≥80% chronic pain patients attend ≥7/10 sessions for each program (70%) • ≥80% chronic pain patients with credibility scores higher than the scale's mid-point (Credibility/Expectancy Scale) • ≥80% chronic pain patients with satisfaction scores higher than the scale's mid-point (Client Satisfaction Scale) Retention

• ≥80% post-treatment, ≥75% 6 months follow up for selfreport, performance based and ActiGraph data (this includes valid data for all participants) Assessments • ≥90% accuracy of standardized protocol checklists for all assessments recruitment procedures to include medical record review at Duke to facilitate recruitment, and to increase the likelihood of reaching racial and ethnic minority participants. Fourth, we solicited feedback from participants about their step goals, and adjusted step goals above 10,000 steps/day with participant input. For example, one group member began commuting twice per day instead of once, which increased her step count from baseline substantially. With her feedback, we elected to maintain her step goal at 10,000 steps/day without increasing it further. Fifth, participants are encouraged to contact the research assistant with technology questions and are offered one-on-one appointments when more extensive training is required.

sections.title: 5.. Discussion
sections.text:
We describe the methodology for a multisite feasibility study of GetActive-Fitbit, a mind-body activity program aimed at improving multimodal physical function and other relevant outcomes among a racially and ethnically diverse sample of individuals with chronic pain recruited from 3 pain clinics from across the US. The study is focused on establishing a training protocol for clinicians, determining feasibility and fidelity benchmarks of our RCT protocol comparing GetActive -Fitbit versus HLP, and optimizing our protocol for a future fully-powered multisite efficacy trial.

Establishing multisite feasibility is essential as it allows for stronger generalizability and is necessary to generate a rate of recruitment for a targeted sample that will permit timely enrollment and long-term follow up in our planned future efficacy trial  [45] . Additionally, multisite feasibility testing will allow us to address limitations of our prior singlesite study including recruitment of racially and ethnically diverse populations, accurate recruitment of the population of interest (i.e., individuals with chronic pain who take <5000 steps/day), and ability to follow up with participants after program completion to understand the sustainability of improvements. We will also be able to further optimize the protocol and explore systemic barriers (through focus groups with staff) to enhance the rigor and success of the future efficacy testing. The information gleaned from the present trial will allow us to more fully understand barriers to implementing the GetActive-Fitbit program that may exist as a result of developing the program at a medical center in the Northeast among a primarily White population. The identification of differences in site culture that act as barriers or facilitators to the feasibility of the protocol will help us improve our ability to implement the protocol more widely, and to tailor it to region-specific populations.

There have been several lessons learned during the ongoing trial. First, following differences in self-reported sedentariness between screening and baseline (resulting from participants changing jobs or introducing new activities into their schedules), we have amended our screening procedures to allow for the screening of smartphone device information related to average step count. This allows us to get a rough estimate of current activity level during the screening process and identify individuals who may not actually be part of our target population. Second, we solicited feedback from participants about their step goals, and adjusted step goals above 10,000 steps/day with participant input. Third, we streamlined the explanation of skills in the GetActive-Fitbit manual to increase opportunities for skills discussion during the check-in period of each session. Lastly, we have adapted the protocol to address needs specific to different sites to better support their recruitment and study implementation efforts, such as incorporating medical record review at Duke to facilitate recruitment. Differences in clinician availability across sites has resulted in a staggered start for group recruitment; this has allowed clinicians from MGH to share information (e.g., questions to anticipate from group participants, examples of effective skill use) to help increase clinician preparedness at other sites. Adjusting the protocol to address the needs of multiple sites is expected to substantially improve our ability to efficiently implement the protocol Note. Participants included in the present table have been consented and randomized/completed baseline assessments.

at new sites in the future. Additional modifications are expected as we continue learning from the present trial.

sections.title: 5.1.. Limitations
sections.text: Despite our emphasis on refining our methodology to reduce barriers to participation and data collection, we anticipate limitations to our approach. Each of the groups will be offered in-person, which may present a barrier to participation among individuals who live far from the hospital or who experience mobility difficulties. Prior participants expressed preference for in person groups because they allow a more intimate atmosphere that can enhance social connection. To mitigate this, we offer $15 for parking and/or transportation for each session attended, with an additional $50 if 8/10 sessions are attended. Future iterations of the program may be delivered remotely to increase accessibility of the intervention.

sections.title: 6.. Conclusion
sections.text: With the current trial, we aim to establish multisite fidelity and optimize our methodology. This work will be used to inform a future efficacy trial that will test whether GetActive-Fitbit is superior to HLP in improving physical and psychosocial function targets among geographically and racially/ethnically diverse sedentary adults with heterogeneous chronic pain. Future iterations of GetActive-Fitbit may include cultural adaptations stemming from collaboration with community partners and telehealth adaptations to increase the program's accessibility and generalizability. The refinement of the protocol used within the present study is a critical step towards this goal, and helps ensure the rigor and success of the subsequent efficacy trial.
